comment: African barbets (Lybiidae) are sisters to the New World barbets and toucans (Moyle 2004)
The species taxonomy of albatrosses is controversial with advocates for 12 to 24 species (BLI, Tennyson 2010, SACC 388, Penhallurick 2012)
The antpittas (Grallariidae) are not closely related to the antthrushes (Formicariidae) and thus are treated as a separate family (Chesser 2004, Rice 2005, SACC)
Asian barbets (Megalaimidae) are the basal outgroup to the African barbets and in turn the New World barbets and toucans (Moyle 2004)
The Oceanitidae and  Hydrobatidae are not sister taxa (Nunn & Stanley 1998; Penhallurick & Wink 2004, Hackett et al. 2008). Resequence Oceanitidae to precede Diomedeidae (H&M4)
DNA sequence studies separate Crested Bellbird, Crested Pitohui and Rufous-naped Whistler as a distinct monophyletic taxon distantly related to other corvoid families (Schodde & Christidis 2014)

Bearded Reedling is not related to parrotbills, but is sister to the larks (Alaudidae) and in turn to the rest of the Sylvioidea (Ericson and Johansson 2003; Alström et al. 2006; Fuchs et al. 2006; Alström et al. 2013)

Donacobius is related to the Old World warblers,not wrens (Troglodytidae);  treated for now as a monotypic family Donacobiidae (Aleixo and Pacheco 2006; SACC 293) pending resolution of relationships to Megaluridae vs Bernieridae (Johansson et al 2008)
Boatbills may belong to the woodswallow - bushshrike assemblage with Peltops (Norman et al. 2009)

The broadbills (family Eurylaimidae) include both the asities of Madagascar and Sapayoa of the New World, and together are the sister group to the pittas (Pittidae) (Irestedt et al. 2006; Moyle 2006a).

family_english: Buntings, New World Sparrows and allies

comment: The Aegithalidae are not closely related to the true tits (Paridae) as once thought (Harrap 2008); hence IOC recommended use of distinguishing name "bushtit" rather than "tit"
The buttonquails (Turnicidae) belong in the Charadriiformes, not the Gruiformes (Hackett et al. 2008)
Expand Daptrius to include Milvago, Phalcoboenus and Ibycter (Fuchs et al 2015)
See Sangster et al 2010, Zuccon & Ericson 2010 for revisions of Muscicapidae
Cockatoos are treated as a family (Christidis and Boles 2008, Joseph et al 2012)

The genera of cormorants and the distinctions between "shags" and "cormorants" remain mostly unresolved due to conflicts among studies and missing taxa (Siegel-Causey 1988, Kennedy et al 2000, Christidis &  Boles 2008). See Kennedy & Spencer 2014 for revised classification under IOC review.
The crescentchests are not tapaculos, but a separate family Melanopareiidae that is one of four basal lineages of  furnariine suboscines  (Chesser 2004, Moyle et al. 2009)
See Fregin et al 2012 for formal proposal of Macrosphenidae, which Includes members of the Sphenoeacus group of Old World warblers separated by Johansson et al (2008)
The correct spelling of this family name is Leptosomidae, not Leptosomatidae (Bock 1994)

Move  Egyptian Plover (Pluvianus) from the Glareolidae to its own family tentatively named "Pluvianidae". It is a separate lineage that is the outgroup to plovers and their allies (Baker et al 2007, Hackett et al. 2008)
Stenostiridae includes Stenostira and Elminia from Incertae Sedis and Culicicapa from Muscicapidae (Barker et al. 2002, 2004; Beresford et al. 2005; Fuchs et al. 2006)
see Jønsson et al 2010 for phylogenetic sequence of species
Classification of Fringillidae revised for v3.3; see especially Zuccon et al 2012
The finfoots (Heliornithidae) and flufftails (Sarothruridae) are sister taxa (Hackett et al. 2008)
The flufftails (Sarothruridae) and finfoots (Heliornithidae) are sister taxa (Hackett et al. 2008)

Recognition of the Asian frogmouths (Batrachosomus) vs Australasian frogmouths (Podargus) as separate families (Christidis and Boles 2008) requires equal consideration for Rigidipenna inexpectatus as a monotypic family (see Tree of Life)
Major clade of babblers treated provisionally as the family Pellorneidae pending full revision
Locustellidae has priority over Megaluridae (Bock 1994, BOU); revised classification (v2.11 )includes  14 species transferred from Bradypterus ( Alström et al 2011a)
The ground hornbills (Bucorvidae) and hornbills (Bucerotidae) and  are sister taxa related in turn to the hoopoes and wood hoopoes (Hackett et al. 2008). Classification follows Gonzalez et al. 2013a.

The skimmers Rynchops and terns are embedded among the gulls in a monophyletic clade; separation of the families Rynchopidae and Sternidae would render the gull family Laridae paraphyletic relative to these other two groups (Baker et al. 2008)
The herons (Ardeidae) and ibises,spoonbills (Threskiornithidae) are sister taxa in the Order Pelecaniformes (Hackett et al. 2008)
Remove Moho to Mohoidae and Notiomystis to Notiomystidae. Revised classification (3.4) of genera and breakup of Lichenostomus follows Nyári & Joseph (2011).
Honeyguides (Indicatoridae) and woodpeckers (Picidae) are sister families (Hackett et al. 2008)
The hoopoes (Upupidae) and wood hoopoes (Phoeniculidae) are sister taxa related in turn to the hornbills (Hackett et al. 2008)
The hornbills (Bucerotidae) and ground hornbills (Bucorvidae) are sister taxa related in turn to the hoopoes and wood hoopoes (Hackett et al. 2008)
Move Hyliotas from the Sylviidae to their own family Hyliotidae, a basal lineage of the Passerida without known modern relatives (Fuchs et al 2006; TOL)
Separate Grey Hypocolius as monotypic family Hypocoliidae to be consistent with treatment of other enigmatic waxwing relatives
Ibises and spoonbills (Threskiornithidae) and herons (Ardeidae) are sister taxa in the Order Pelecaniformes (Hackett et al. 2008)

The jacamars (Galbulidae) and puffbirds (Bucconidae) are well-established sister taxa (SACC,Hackett et al. 2008), with evidence favoring inclusion in the Piciformes, rather than a separate Order Galbuliformes (TOL, Ericson et al. 2006; cf SACC, Fain & Hou
The Kagu (Rhynochetidae) and Sunbittern (Eurypygidae) are sister taxa (Hackett et al. 2008).

The kingfishers (Alcedinidae) comprise three monophyletic clades (Alcedininae, Cerylinae, and Daceloninae) (Moyle 2006); some taxonomists elevate them to family status (Sibley and Monroe 1990, Christidis and Boles 2008)
Classification of Accipitridae revised v3.3; see especially Wink & Sauer-Gürth 2004, Lerner & Mindell 2005, TIF)
Kiwis and elephant birds (Dinornis) are sister taxa (Mitchell et al 2014).
Major clade of babblers treated provisionally as the family Leiothrichidae pending full revision

Many species of Phylloscopus leaf warblers belong in Seicercus (Johansson et al. 2007, Olsson et al. 2005 Boyd TiF website), but we await the results of a new multilocus analysis of the structure of the Phylloscopidae now underway (Alstrom)
Move longspurs Calcarius and snow buntings Plectrophenax from Emberizidae to their own family Calcariidae (Alström et al 2008)
The Magellanic Plover (Pluvianellus) is most closely related to the sheathbills (Chionidae) (REF).

Melampittas are related to birds-of-paradise and Australian mudnesters (Jønsson et al. 2011; Aggerbeck et al 2014, Schodde & Christidis 2014). Move melampittas from Incertae sedis to new family Melampittidae
Toucans and New World barbets are sister taxa  (Moyle 2004, SACC 7) elevated to separate families to reflect their phylogeny (NACC 2010)
SACC 361 elevates the New World Vultures (Cathartidae) to a separate order, the Cathartiformes
Genera and species sequences follow Lovette et al 2010 and AOU/NACC 2011 (supplement)
The New Zealand parrots (Strigops, Nestor) are an ancient, basal lineage that is sister to all other parrots (Psittacidae).
Correct spelling of family name is "Callaeidae", not "Callaeatidae" (Bock 1994, H&M Corrigenda); Change family name to New Zealand Wattlebirds per NZ Checklist Committee, B.J. Gill (Convener) 2010
New Zealand wrens are sister to the rest of the Passeriformes

Move Nicator species from Incertae Sedis to Nicatoridae, which aligns with Alaudidae and Panuridae to form a basal trichotomy that is sister of the rest of the sylvioids (Beresford et al 2005, Johansson et al 2008)

The eared nightjars Eurostopodus are the sister taxon to rest of the Caprimulgidae (Barrowclough et al 2006, Larsen et al. 2007), but they are not equivalent in rank to other families in the Caprimulgiformes.
The Oceanitidae and  Hydrobatidae are not sister taxa (Nunn & Stanley 1998; Penhallurick & Wink 2004, Hackett et al. 2008).
Olive Warbler Peucedramus of New World most closely related to accentors (Prunellidae) (Ericson and Johansson 2003, Jønsson  and Fjeldså 2006)
Species of Moho are related to waxwings (Bombycillidae), not to honeyeaters (Meliphagidae) (Fleischer et al. 2008)
Icteridae classification follows Powell et al 2014
RESTORE: Ospreys to the family Pandionidae in accord with the Tree of Life phylogeny (Hackett et al. 2008)
The ovenbird family Furnariidae includes the phylogenetically embedded woodcreepers, formerly separated as the family Dendrocolaptidae (SACC 132)

The owlet-nightjars (Aegothelidae) are the sister taxon to treeswifts and in turn to the swifts and hummingbirds; hence are included in the Apodiformes (Hackett et al. 2008, Christidis and Boles 2008)
Separate the oxpeckers from the Sturnidae to the Buphagidae; they are sister to the starlings (Mimidae) and mockingbirds (Mimidae) (Lovette and Rubenstein 2007)
Separate the painted berrypeckers (Oreocharis and Paramythia) from the Melanocharitidae to the Paramythiidae  (Barker et al 2004; HBW)

The jacamars (Galbulidae) and puffbirds (Bucconidae) are well-established sister taxa (SACC,Hackett et al. 2008), with evidence favoring inclusion in the Piciformes, rather than a separate Order Galbuliformes (TOL, Ericson et al. 2006; cf SACC, Fain & Hou
Restrict Eupetidae to Rail-babbler Eupetes; resequence as sister to Chaetops and in turn to Picathartes (Jønsson et al. 2007)
Rockfowl, rockjumpers, and rail-babbler form an ancient clade that is sister to the Petroica and in turn to the Passerida (Jønsson et al. 2007)
RESTORE: Secretarybird to a monotypic family Sagittariidae in accord with the Tree of Life phylogeny (Hackett et al. 2008)
Follow AOU 1998 in recognizing silky flycatchers as a separate family Ptiliogonatidae. Change spelling to follow original spelling of genus Ptiliogonys.
Includes major revisions of genera by Lovette et al (2008), Zuccon et al (2008)
Stitchbird is related to the wattled crows of New Zealand, not to honeyeaters (Meliphagidae) (Driskell et al 2007)
Major clade of babblers treated provisionally as the family Sylviidae pending full revision
Revised classification follows Johansson et al 2013; see also Tietze & Borthakur 2012
The genera placed in the family Tityridae are more closely related to the manakins (Pipridae) than to the cotingas (Cotingidae) (Chesser 2004, Barber and Rice 2007, SACC)
Sequence of New World trogons follows AOU in accord with DaCosta and Klicka (2008) and Moyle (2005)
Proposed revision of trumpeter species taxonomy under review (Ribas et al 2012, SACC 607)
Vireonidae includes Erpornis and Pteruthius (Reddy and Cracraft 2007, Reddy 2008)
Psophodidae provisionally includes Ptilorrhoa and Cinclosoma formerly in Eupetidae following Christidis and Boles (2008); should be separated to the Cinclosomatidae (Norman et al 2009)

Its composition in flux, Pachycephalidae includes Colluricincla, but excludes Oreoica (Oreoicidae), Rhagologus (Rhagologidae), and Pitohui sensu stricto (Oriolidae) (Jønsson et al 2008, Dumbacher 2008); also remove Hylocitrea, a bombycillid (Spellman et al. 2008). Falcunculus is a questionable member of Pachycephalidae (Zuccon & Ericson, 2012)
White-eyes constitute a major clade of babblers that includes Yuhina (Cibois et al. 2003); retain as family Zosteropidae pending full revision of babbler taxa
Change status of Mohoua species (including Finschia) from Incertae sedis to follow Campephagidae as a monophyletic family in core Corvoidea (Aidala et al 2013)
The hoopoes (Upupidae) and wood hoopoes (Phoeniculidae) are sister taxa related in turn to the hornbills (Hackett et al. 2008)

Artamidae includes previous Cracticidae. Woodswallows, butcherbirds and Peltops are equidistant (subfamily) lineages in one monophyletic cluster (Norman et al. 2009b, Jønsson et al. 2010, Jønsson et al. 2011, Aggerbeck et al. 2014, Schodde & Christidis 2014, J Fjeldsa comm.)
Pnoepyga wren-babblers are not babblers and elevated to their own family (Gelang et al. 2009)
